introduction.p: Sometimes radical notation is more convenient to use than exponents. In these cases, we usually simplify radical expressions algebraically before using a calculator to obtain decimal approximations.

subsection.title: Properties of Radicals
subsection.p: Because \sqrt[n]{a}=a^{1/n}, we can use the laws of exponents to derive two important properties that are useful in working with radicals.
As examples, you can verify that \sqrt{36}=\sqrt{4}\sqrt{9} ~~~\text{ and }~~~ \sqrt[3]{\frac{1}{8}}=\frac{\sqrt[3]{1}}{\sqrt[3]{8}}

warning.p: In general, it is not true that \sqrt[n]{a+b} is equivalent to \sqrt[n]{a}+\sqrt[n]{b}, or that \sqrt[n]{a-b} is equivalent to \sqrt[n]{a}-\sqrt[n]{b}.

solution.p: The statements in (b) and (d) are true, and both are examples of the first property of radicals.

exercise.title: Practice 1
exercise.p:
Which of the following are true?
\sqrt[3]{8a^3-b^3} = 2a-b~?
\sqrt[5]{x^3y^4} = \sqrt[5]{x^3}\sqrt[5]{y^4}~?
\sqrt[4]{\dfrac{1}{w^4}}=\dfrac{1}{w}, for w \gt 0~?
\sqrt{1+x^2} = 1+x~?

subsection.title: Simplifying Radicals
subsection.p: Each time we use a calculator to approximate a radical, we lose accuracy, and in the course of a long calculation, the error accumulates. To avoid this problem, we simplify radicals by factoring out any perfect powers from the radicand.

warning.p: Finding a decimal approximation for a radical is not the same as simplifying the radical. In Example 1, we can use a calculator to find \sqrt[3]{108} \approx 4.762 but 4.762 is not the exact value for \sqrt[3]{108}.

In long calculations, too much error may be introduced by approximating each radical. However, 3 \sqrt[3]{4} is equal to \sqrt[3]{108}, so their values are exactly the same. We can replace one expression by the other without losing accuracy.

subsection.p: We can also simplify radicals containing variables. If the exponent on the variable is a multiple of the index, we can extract the variable from the radical. For instance, \sqrt[3]{12}=x^{12/3}=x^4 (You can verify this by noting that (x^4)^3 = x^{12}.)

warning.p: Do not confuse \sqrt{a^{16}} with \sqrt{16}. Compare the two radicals: \sqrt{16}=4~~~~~~\text{but}~~~~~~\sqrt{a^{16}}=a^8

subsection.p: To simplify a root of a monomial, we factor the coefficient and each power of a variable separately.

statement.p: Hint: Look for perfect cube factors of 250b^7. Apply the product Rule. Take cube roots.

warning.p: It is worth stating again that the Product Rule applies only to products under the radical, not to sums or differences. For example, \sqrt{4\cdot 9}=\sqrt{4}\sqrt{9}=2\cdot 3, ~~~\text{ but }~~~\sqrt{4+ 9}\ne \sqrt{4}+\sqrt{9} and \sqrt[3]{x^3y^6}=\sqrt[3]{x^3}\sqrt[3]{y^6}=xy^2, ~~~\text{ but }~~~\sqrt[3]{x^3-y^6}\ne x-y^2

statement.p:
True or false.
To simplify a radical means to find a decimal approximation.
\sqrt{x^{16}} = x^4
We cannot simplify \sqrt[3]{x^{10}}.
\sqrt{83^5} = 83^2\sqrt{83}

subsection.title: Sums and Differences of Radicals

assemblage.title: Like Radicals
assemblage.p: To add or subtract like radicals, we add or subtract their coefficients. We do not change the index or the radicand.

li.p: In a, 3\sqrt{3}+4\sqrt{3}\ne 7\sqrt{6} . Only the coefficients are added; the radicand does not change.

statement.p:
True or false.
We combine like radicals the same way we combine like terms: by adding or subtracting their coefficients.
To add radicals with different indices, we multiply the indices.
3\sqrt{5}+6\sqrt{5}=9\sqrt{10}
Like radicals must have identical coefficients.

subsection.p: Sometimes we must simplify the roots in a sum or difference before we can recognize like radicals.

subsection.title: Products and Quotients of Radicals
subsection.p: Because of the Product and Quotient Rules, we can multiply or divide radicals of the same index. \sqrt[n]{a}\sqrt[n]{b} \amp = \sqrt[n]{ab} \amp \amp (a,b \ge 0) \dfrac{\sqrt[n]{a}}{\sqrt[n]{b}} \amp = \sqrt[n]{\dfrac{a}{b}} \amp \amp (a \ge 0, b \gt 0) These rules tell us that for products and quotients, the radicands do not have to be the same; only the indices must match.
For products involving binomials, we apply the distributive law.

statement.p:
True or false.
We can only simplify products or quotients of like radicals.
4(3\sqrt{5} = 3 \cdot 4 + 3\sqrt{5}
(\sqrt{3}+\sqrt{5})^2 = 3+5=8
(3\sqrt{x})^2=9x

subsection.title: Rationalizing the Denominator
subsection.p: It is easier to work with radicals if there are no roots in the denominators of fractions. We can use the fundamental principle of fractions to remove radicals from the denominator. This process is called rationalizing the denominatorrationalizing the denominator. For square roots, we multiply the numerator and denominator of the fraction by the radical in the denominator.

If the denominator of a fraction is a binomial in which one or both terms is a radical, we can use a special building factor to rationalize it. First, recall that (p - q) (p + q) = p^2 - q^2 In particular, then, (\sqrt{b}-\sqrt{c})(\sqrt{b}+\sqrt{c}) = (\sqrt{b})^2-(\sqrt{c})^2 = b-c The product contains no radicals. Each of the two factors \sqrt{b}-\sqrt{c} and \sqrt{b}+\sqrt{c} is said to be the conjugateconjugate of the other.

statement.p:

To rationalize a binomial denominator, we multiply by its .
